body: The problem is `"minimum-stability": "dev"` mixed with an older version of PHPUnit. You ended up with the 1.2.x-dev version of `php-code-coverage` which is not compatible with PHPUnit 3.7.19. Updating to PHPUnit 3.7.20 should fix this issue.

I see. Haven't tested your suggestion, but thanks for the solution. 

PHPUnit 3.7.19 says in it's composer.json it works with php-code-coverage >=1.2.1,<1.3.0

Then someone made a commit in the 1.2.x branch of php-code-coverage that apparently broke backwards compatibility.

If someone had to break backwards compatibility of php-code-coverage, the major version should be bumped not the bugfix version.. see http://semver.org/

Or alternatively, if you refuse to have backwards compatibility in php-code-coverage, then PHPUnit should depend on a specific tag like "1.2.1" so that automatic updates (that potentially break it) aren't pulled in.
Yeah, I was sort of confused by this BC break as well. Maybe @sebastianbergmann can shed some light on this situation for us.

Now that I've had a second to look into this, I don't think `"minimum-stability": "dev"` really has anything to do with the problem. Unless I'm mistaken, looks like text coverage will be broken in `3.7.19` when installed with PEAR or composer unless the correct version of php-code-coverage is explicitly required.

The `package.xml` in the `3.7` branch has a dependency on PHP_CodeCoverage >= 1.2.10 and <= 1.2.99 and the `composer.json` has `"phpunit/php-code-coverage": ">=1.2.10,<1.3.0"` it it since the API change. As far as I can see, this can only result in a problem if you update either PHPUnit or PHP_CodeCoverage without updating the other. But why would you do that?

Right, the problem is if you explicitly install an older version of PHPUnit 3.7, you will get the newer version of php-code-coverage.

**composer.json**

``` json
{
    "require-dev": {
        "phpunit/phpunit": "3.7.19"
    }
}
```

**composer.phar install --dev**

```
Loading composer repositories with package information
Installing dependencies (including require-dev)
  - Installing symfony/yaml (v2.2.1)
    Loading from cache

  - Installing phpunit/php-text-template (1.1.4)
    Loading from cache

  - Installing phpunit/phpunit-mock-objects (1.2.3)
    Loading from cache

  - Installing phpunit/php-timer (1.0.4)
    Loading from cache

  - Installing phpunit/php-token-stream (1.1.5)
    Loading from cache

  - Installing phpunit/php-file-iterator (1.3.3)
    Loading from cache

  - Installing phpunit/php-code-coverage (1.2.10)
    Loading from cache

  - Installing phpunit/phpunit (3.7.19)
    Loading from cache

phpunit/phpunit suggests installing phpunit/php-invoker (>=1.1.0,<1.2.0)
Writing lock file
Generating autoload files
```

Now notice the text coverage is missing:

```
[whatthejeff@phpunit test]$ vendor/bin/phpunit --coverage-text tests/
PHPUnit 3.7.19 by Sebastian Bergmann.

.

Time: 0 seconds, Memory: 7.25Mb

OK (1 test, 1 assertion)
[whatthejeff@phpunit test]$
```

But if I force composer to install the proper version of php-code-coverage, it works:

```
[whatthejeff@phpunit test]$ vendor/bin/phpunit --coverage-text tests/
PHPUnit 3.7.19 by Sebastian Bergmann.

.

Time: 0 seconds, Memory: 7.25Mb

OK (1 test, 1 assertion)


Code Coverage Report 
  2013-05-23 02:23:25

 Summary: 
  Classes: 33.33% (1/3)
  Methods: 6.67% (1/15)
  Lines:   7.00% (7/100)

My
  Methods: 100.00% ( 1/ 1)   Lines: 100.00% (  1/  1)
\Composer\Autoload::ClassLoader
  Methods:  16.67% ( 2/12)   Lines:   8.00% (  6/ 75)
[whatthejeff@phpunit test]$
```

> this can only result in a problem if you update either PHPUnit or PHP_CodeCoverage without updating the other. 

That's not right, I don't think. Well maybe, but not in a way that makes sense to a user. Basically you're saying to only depend on phpunit-3.7.*, I want to depend on a specific version, like phpunit-3.7.19.

All I did was require your package "phpunit-3.7.19". I tested my project & it worked. I cloned it on another machine a few days later and it stopped working. No one can use phpunit-3.7.19 anymore**. It once worked, it now does not. You're forcing me to upgrade phpunit when I don't want to. There's a few solutions going forward
- php-code-coverage must adhere to http://semver.org and not break BC due to a "bugfix". The changes that caused the --coverage-text to stop working should have been released in a new major version of php-code-coverage, such that users of phpunit-3.7.19 do not get those updates, rendering their installation broken.
- PHPUnit must state it's dependency on a specific version of php-code-coverage.

*\* that is, no one can use this particular feature, without fixing the mismatched dependencies it sets up by default.

It's not just 3.7.19; text code coverage will be broken for people installing any older versions of PHPUnit 3.7 as it will come with php-code-coverage 1.2.10 unless a compatible version is explicitly specified.
I think what makes the most sense is release a new bugfix version of php-code-coverage that restores BC.

PHPUnit 3.7.21 and PHP_CodeCoverage 1.2.11 have been tagged. Unfortunately, I am currently not able to release the PEAR packages due to an issue with `pear.phpundercontrol.org`:

`pear.phpundercontrol.org` is offline for the time being. Problem "solved" (as in: worked around) by removing old PHP_CodeBrowser releases from `pear.phpunit.de` until `pear.phpundercontrol.org` is back online.

issue.title: Reverted changes since php-code-coverage shows decoupling the Result Printer was reverted.
